items.title: Scores are not matching readme
Just making sure, ROUGE scores are within [0, 1] right?
items.body:
Common sense tells me that for all three available scores (i.e. `rouge-1`, `rouge-2`, and `rouge-l`) the values for each entry should be between [0, 1], but I'm getting values like 7.8 and 6.4 for `rouge-2` for some of my stuff.

I'm assuming that there's also a problem on my side, but just wanted to make sure.

items.title: the rouge only work when sentence number of the hyp and the ref are the same?
items.body:
hello~~  
in your code file: rouge.py
there
`def get_scores(self, hyps, refs, avg=False, ignore_empty=False):
        if isinstance(hyps, six.string_types):
            hyps, refs = [hyps], [refs]

        if ignore_empty:
            # Filter out hyps of 0 length
            hyps_and_refs = zip(hyps, refs)
            hyps_and_refs = [_ for _ in hyps_and_refs
                             if len(_[0]) > 0
                             and len(_[1]) > 0]
            hyps, refs = zip(*hyps_and_refs)

        assert(isinstance(hyps, type(refs)))
        **assert(len(hyps) == len(refs))`**
it means the num of sentences must the same in the hyp and the ref? 
i come to this when my hyp and ref are list of str like: hyp=[''this is a example","this is another example"],ref=[''this is a example","this is another example","this is last example"], which invoke the assert error.

maybe i misunderstand the format needed for the hyp and ref?

Thanks!

items.title: Running the provided example but getting an empty dict as output.
items.body: Hi. I'm running the example line by line as is shown in the README file, but I'm getting an empty dictionary as the output. Any insight on how I can fix this and what might be the cause? Thanks.

items.title: ROUGE-L sets exclusive=True
items.body:
rouge_l_summary_level sets exclusive=True (https://github.com/pltrdy/rouge/blob/master/rouge/rouge_score.py#L371)

Is there a reason for doing so? In particular as exclusive=False is the default option

items.title: Rouge of sentence pair not matching results in the README
items.body:
```
>>> import json
>>> from rouge import Rouge
>>> 
>>> hypothesis = "the #### transcript is a written version of each day 's cnn student news program use this transcript to he    lp students with reading comprehension and vocabulary use the weekly newsquiz to test your knowledge of storie s you     saw on cnn student news"
>>> 
>>> reference = "this page includes the show transcript use the transcript to help students with reading comprehension and     vocabulary at the bottom of the page , comment for a chance to be mentioned on cnn student news . you must be a teac    her or a student age # # or older to request a mention on the cnn student news roll call . the weekly newsquiz tests     students ' knowledge of even ts in the news"
>>> 
>>> rouge = Rouge()
>>> scores = rouge.get_scores(hypothesis, reference)
>>> scores
```
[{'rouge-1': {'f': 0.4786324739396596, 'p': 0.6363636363636364, 'r': 0.3835616438356164}, 'rouge-2': {'f': 0.2608695605353498, 'p': 0.3488372093023256, 'r': 0.20833333333333334}, 'rouge-l': {'f': 0.5128205081276938, 'p': 0.6818181818181818, 'r': 0.410958904109589}}]

items.title: Lengths of Reference and System Summaries
items.body:
Hi,
I am using this packing for evaluation. 
Thank you for a python developed version of Rouge.
However, I am concerned about why equal lengths of reference and system summaries are required. 
To my understanding, there should be no restriction for equal lengths.
Please check the following link:
https://rxnlp.com/how-rouge-works-for-evaluation-of-summarization-tasks/#.Xd-VSFlKg2c

May you please provide any explanation of your code condition for equal lengths.
Looking forward for your kind response.

items.title: Not working. Help!
items.body:
I am following the example found in the readme file using rouge as a library but when I pass the original summary and the predicted summary as a string rouge scores are all 0. Can you help me with this issue please ? I have uploaded an image for your referrence.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16855972/58240593-9c4fb780-7d4b-11e9-8f84-61aac42b7ec8.png)

items.title: No module named 'bin' after pip install
items.body:
After successfully installing using `pip install rouge` , I get the following when trying `rouge -h`
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/rouge", line 6, in <module>
    from bin.rouge_cmd import main
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'bin'
```
I do not get this error when installing using `git clone`.

items.title: Test results across different versions
items.body:
I was trying to reproduce the scores with the following setup containing only the first sample from  your https://github.com/pltrdy/rouge/blob/master/tests/data.json:

*File 1: hyp.txt:* "the #### transcript is a written version of each day 's cnn student news program use this transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary use the weekly newsquiz to test your knowledge of storie s you saw on cnn student news"

*File 2 ref.txt:* "this page includes the show transcript use the transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary at the bottom of the page , comment for a chance to be mentioned on cnn student news . you must be a teacher or a student age # # or older to request a mention on the cnn student news roll call . the weekly newsquiz tests students ' knowledge of even ts in the news"


**1: Rouge v0.3.0:**

```bash
$ pip install rouge==0.3.0
$ rouge -f ./hyp.txt ./ref.txt
[
  {
    "rouge-1": {
      "f": 0.5411764657051903,
      "p": 0.6388888888888888,
      "r": 0.46938775510204084
    },
    "rouge-2": {
      "f": 0.27272726805123976,
      "p": 0.36585365853658536,
      "r": 0.21739130434782608
    },
    "rouge-l": {
      "f": 0.45001673716547075,
      "p": 0.5555555555555556,
      "r": 0.40816326530612246
    }
  }
]
```

**2: Rouge 0.2.0**

```bash
$ pip install rouge==0.2.0
$ rouge -f ./hyp.txt ./ref.txt
[
  {
    "rouge-1": {
      "f": 0.5348837160627367,
      "p": 0.6388888888888888,
      "r": 0.46
    },
    "rouge-2": {
      "f": 0.26785713821588014,
      "p": 0.36585365853658536,
      "r": 0.2112676056338028
    },
    "rouge-l": {
      "f": 0.28711800978275975,
      "p": 0.4418604651162791,
      "r": 0.25675675675675674
    }
  }
]
```
As you can see, the resuls for `rouge-l` are very different. However, the second results from version `0.2.0` equal the test data results of https://github.com/pltrdy/rouge/blob/master/tests/data.json. 

**3: Run with files2rouge from https://github.com/pltrdy/files2rouge** 
```bash
files2rouge hyp.txt ref.txt
Preparing documents...
Running ROUGE...
---------------------------------------------
1 ROUGE-1 Average_R: 0.69048 (95%-conf.int. 0.69048 - 0.69048)
1 ROUGE-1 Average_P: 0.42647 (95%-conf.int. 0.42647 - 0.42647)
1 ROUGE-1 Average_F: 0.52727 (95%-conf.int. 0.52727 - 0.52727)
---------------------------------------------
1 ROUGE-2 Average_R: 0.43902 (95%-conf.int. 0.43902 - 0.43902)
1 ROUGE-2 Average_P: 0.26866 (95%-conf.int. 0.26866 - 0.26866)
1 ROUGE-2 Average_F: 0.33333 (95%-conf.int. 0.33333 - 0.33333)
---------------------------------------------
1 ROUGE-L Average_R: 0.57143 (95%-conf.int. 0.57143 - 0.57143)
1 ROUGE-L Average_P: 0.35294 (95%-conf.int. 0.35294 - 0.35294)
1 ROUGE-L Average_F: 0.43636 (95%-conf.int. 0.43636 - 0.43636)
``` 
which is again different to the results in 1 and 2.


I know there are differences between the original perl implementation and the python reimplementation. But am I missing something or what is the reason for the very different results?

items.title: rouge-L total number of words in sentences
items.body:
thanks for making useful library.
I got a question about implementing of ROUGE-L

In code, To get "m" and "n",  you used len(**set**(_split_into_words(reference_sentences))).
but in paper, it does not seem number of unique words.
I am not familiar in perl code, but original perl code also does not seem unique words.

is there some reason you use unique words count?

items.title: Calculating average rouge score on 2 files manually
items.body:
Hi,

I'm using this package to measure rouge on 2 sets of files. (Prediction and Gold)

As it's indicated, one way is to use FilesRouge class which computes the average score on 2 files having the same # of lines. 

But what I want to do is to compute average rouge manually. So I used the single sentence approach in a for loop, but the results are not the same with the first approach (using FilesRouge). Does anybody have an idea to how handle this?

```
# content : array of predictions, and contentRef: array of gold summaries
for i in range(len(contentRef)):
        count = count + 1
        roug = Rouge()
        score = roug.get_scores(content[i], contentRef[i])
        scoreAvgR1R += score[0].get("rouge-1")["f"]
        scoreAvgR1P += score[0].get("rouge-2")["f"]
        scoreAvgR1F += score[0].get("rouge-l")["f"]

scoreAvgR1R = scoreAvgR1R/count
scoreAvgR1P = scoreAvgR1P/count
scoreAvgR1F = scoreAvgR1F/count

print("Total evaluated sentences: " + str(count) +"\n")
print("ROUGE-1 : " + str(scoreAvgR1R) +"\n")
print("ROUGE-2 : " + str(scoreAvgR1P) + "\n")
print("ROUGE-l : " + str(scoreAvgR1F) + "\n")
```

items.title: Emtpy string cannot be evaluated with 0.3.0
items.body:
When an empty string is passed a sentence to be evaluated (which can very easily happen at early stages of training a system), the scoring crashes in rouge/rouge.py, line 159.

```ipython
In [2]: import rouge
In [3]: rouge = rouge.Rouge()
In [4]: hyps = ['']
In [5]: ref = ['foo']
In [6]: rouge.get_scores(hyps, ref)
```

items.title: NameError: name 'string_types' is not defined
items.body:
Hey,
You forgot to define 'string_types', I guess you meant to str (relate to python 3)

items.title: NameError: global name 'unicode' is not defined
items.body:
This line may cause an error. I just replace to `if type(hyps) == str:` and it works.
https://github.com/pltrdy/rouge/blob/master/rouge/rouge.py#L73

Reference to:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19877306/nameerror-global-name-unicode-is-not-defined-in-python-3

items.body:
while using the library, I got the following error 
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 33: ordinal not in range(128)

at 
split_into_words
    return list(itertools.chain(*[_.split(" ") for _ in sentences]))

How should I fix it?

items.title: Typo in documentation
items.body:
Hi, I noticed an error in the documentation you have on PyPI (maybe it's used elsewhere as well):

```python
from rouge import Rouge 

hypothesis = "the #### transcript is a written version of each day 's cnn student news program use this transcript to he lp students with reading comprehension and vocabulary use the weekly newsquiz to test your knowledge of storie s you saw on cnn student news"

reference = "this page includes the show transcript use the transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary at the bottom of the page , comment for a chance to be mentioned on cnn student news . you must be a teac her or a student age # # or older to request a mention on the cnn student news roll call . the weekly newsquiz tests students ' knowledge of even ts in the news"

rouge = Rouge()
scores = rouge.get_scores(reference, hypothesis)
```

according to the code (and the examples below this excerpt), hypothesis should go first.

items.title: Rouge score accuracy
items.body:
The results are known to be quite different from official ROUGE scoring script. 

It has been discussed here:
https://github.com/google/seq2seq/issues/89

items.title: python2 support?
items.body:
Are you planning to support python 2? 
I feel minimal changes will make it runnable on python2.
